You've done a great job explaining basic circuit analysis. However, you are wrong in your assumption that current flows from positive to negative. Current is defined as the flow of electrons in a circuit. Electrons are negatively charged and they move to the positively charged atoms. Positively charged atoms are those that have a deficiency of electrons (holes). Ben Franklin is credited with developing. "conventional current" theory. It was disproved 150 years later by JJ Johnson who discovered the electron. The good thing about this is it doesn't matter which theory you believe, conventional or electron. It doesn't affect how you construct and or analyze circuits.  http://web.engr.oregonstate.edu/~traylor/ece112/beamer_lectures/elect_flow_vs_conv_I.pdf      http://web.engr.oregonstate.edu/~traylor/ece112/beamer_lectures/elect_flow_vs_conv_I.pdf

You got one thing fundamentally wrong. According to you it should look like this A=V/ohms  Formula does not use units for symbols. Current is for I, resistance is for R, tension is for U. I unit is Ampere, R unit is Ohm, U unit is Volts.

In the early days of electrical science, scientist and engineers concluded that electrons flowed from the positive terminal to the negative terminal. This is evident by the direction of the arrow that was drawn on diodes or BJT transistors. These schematic symbols were drawn earlier in the 1800s and 1900s, before the quantum facts of electricity could be proven.   But, when the electron microscope was invented, we discovered that the opposite was true. The excess electrons flowed from the Negative terminal toward the Positive terminal.  This is not an opinion, but scientific fact and was observed by the electron microscope. I find it interesting that the more recent invention of FETs (Field Effect Transistors), that the direction of current was corrected. I think you should correct your videos or not talk about the quantum aspects of this science.

mark james it doesn't matter what you think, everything will still work the same regardless, you just have to reverse everything on paper. Like the diode and transistor flow direction. Its just two differing theories, and no one knows 100% which one is correct.
They definitely know.  http://amasci.com/amateur/elecdir.html

That he described was electron flow, which is actually what happens.  However, before people knew anything about electrons, they thought it was positive charges that flowed. It became the convention, after the discovery of the existence of electrons, to remain with that old thinking however; from this you have "conventional flow".  They're still effectively the same since they're relative, just gotta see the necessary stuff in a circuit in reverse, essentially.
